item.title: Size Matters, Here's Why [Early Tix To Our First Lecture of 2026]
item.description: Why do animals and humans grow only to a certain size? Join us for a lecture by Dr Carmen Coelho, Faculty at Centre of Human Genetics, Bangalore.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
When we first shared the poster and details of our upcoming lecture with our venue and drink partners, their reaction was completely unexpected.

The instinctive response from their teams was not logistical or promotional. It was a curious, “This is such a fascinating topic!”

Here’s the big reveal: Our first lecture of the year is…

Book tickets

So, how does an animal know when to stop growing? How does a body arrive at the size it does—neither too small nor too large—without a measuring tape, a reference chart, or a final instruction saying stop?

To explore these questions, we will have Dr. Carmen Coelho, a developmental biologist and researcher at the Centre for Human Genetics.

Carmen’s work sits at a beautiful intersection of biology, curiosity and humility. She studies how organs and bodies regulate their final size using the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster as a model system. It sounds straightforward until you realise how deep the question really goes.

Every animal begins life as a single egg cell. These egg cells vary dramatically in size—across species and even within them. Mammalian eggs are among the smallest. Bird eggs can be among the largest. And yet, the size of the egg does not neatly predict the size of the adult that eventually emerges from it.

From egg to embryo. From embryo to organism. Some animals continue growing slowly throughout their lives. Others stop at a very specific point. What determines this trajectory? Is it hormones? Nutrition? Genetics? Timing?

The honest answer is that we do not fully know.

Much of Carmen’s research challenges long-held assumptions in developmental biology. One such assumption is that organs follow a rigid growth blueprint, or that they are constantly “measuring” themselves as they grow. Instead, her work shows that early development is filled with variation. Organs can start out larger or smaller than average, and yet, over time, most of this variation is corrected. Growth compensates. Final size stabilises.

This leads to a fascinating possibility: What if growth is not about constant measurement, but about memory?

Carmen’s work suggests that growth rates depend on developmental history, on where an organ has already been, rather than on continuous monitoring of size. It is a subtle shift, but one that deeply changes how we think about biological regulation.

Alongside this, Carmen also studies cell competition: a phenomenon where faster-growing cells eliminate slower-growing neighbours. First discovered in fruit flies, this process is now known to exist across species and plays a crucial role in tissue health, development, and cancer. Understanding how cells compete, cooperate, and sometimes overtake each other helps us understand how bodies remain healthy, and what happens when they don’t.

What excites us most is how these questions scale.

From a fly’s wing to a human organ.
From an egg cell to adulthood.
From normal development to disease.

Carmen’s work speaks to catch-up growth, overgrowth disorders, and how early developmental differences can echo far longer than we expect. Come, learn how biologists think when faced with questions that are fundamental, unresolved, and quietly profound.

• Wednesday, 7 January 2026

• 7:00 PM – 9:00 PM

• Away Center, Koramangala

item.title: [Music Lecture Alert] End 2025 with a Song of Your Own in this Rare Experience at Manyata + Kora!
item.description: We bring you one of the most original singers-songwriters we know, Ava M, who's coming all the way from Goa to teach you how to make a song!
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dearest secret-hummers, bathroom-singers, instrument-hoarders,

No matter where you are in your musical journey, Pint of View’s second experience will leave you quenched. Have you ever tried writing a song? What if we told you our next speaker will make songwriting and composition feel so intuitive that you’ll wonder why you didn’t try it earlier?

We are elated to bring to you Ava M, one of the most original singers and songwriters we know for a songwriting and composition workshop titled How To Make A Song? End your 2025 with a song of your own.

Ava, aka Avantika, lives and breathes music. Let one of her reels show what we mean. This is her composing her own song, and then merging it with the song of a bird.

@ava.atplay
Avantika M on Instagram: "Was trying to make a song, ended up j…

Or her first single:

Or this slow burn:

@ava.atplay
Avantika M on Instagram: "Covid lungs day 13 but feeling stretc…

Here’s more about the lecture:

Learn what makes a song, from the inside out.

In this lecture-cum-workshop, Ava takes you on an immersive journey through lyrics, rhythm, and melody. Beginning with the deconstruction of popular songs — from Hanumankind’s Run It Up to the logic of polyrhythms — you’ll learn how to hear and identify the inherent beat that holds a song together.

From there, the session gently moves into scales and melodies, not as theory-heavy abstractions but as tools you can actually use. All of this builds toward what brings us to music in the first place: songwriting.

You’ll learn how to write songs, how to shape ideas into structure, and how almost anything can become a song when told as a story. Expect participation, exploration, and so many surprises along the way.

About the speaker (—should we say, singer?):

Ava first understood music through the community singing clans of Vrindavan. She grew up being part of this culture, but didn't realise how much it shaped her until she left home.

In Tamil Nadu, Ava worked with fishing communities, teaching kids who were the first in their families to go to school, teaching them English through songs.

She says, “We wrote about their lives, their villages, their feelings. Sang together. That work changed how I see music — not as performance, but as a way to stay human.”

These days, Ava runs an outdoor skincare brand. She surfs and teaches surfing. She dives. And she’s finally putting out her own music.

Tickets

Since this is a small 60-spots only experience, we’re hosting Avantika for the entire last week of 2025 in Bengaluru, and hosting two back to back experiences, on Wednesday 31st at Bier Garten in Manyata (yay, first time in North Bangalore!) and once on Sunday, the 28th, at The Bangalore Local in Koramangala.

As is usual, our early birds go for our subscribers at first. There are 20 early bird tickets in both, so grab them fast based on your preferred location.

Here are the two ticket slots: Manyata one is cheaper, as it’s day time!

Sun, 5PM, 28th Dec, Koramangala

Wed, 1PM, 31st Dec, Manyata

Note that both are the same lecture, so don’t book it twice—unless you love it so much that you want to attend once more!

Here’s an additional perk! Our co-founders are into music too, and we’d be getting a dozen of our instruments (viz. handpan, kokoriko, rainmaker, khadtals, shakers, piano, pianica and obv. a bunch of guitars) for the audience to play while we end the workshop with Ava’s performance and her singing of songs that you write.

Musically yours,
Harsh & Shruti
Pint of View

item.title: [Wednesday Lecture Alert] Our First Economics Lecture is also an Anthropology Lecture!
item.description: We're delighted to host Dr. Archana Rangaswamaiah, an economic anthropologist at Azim Premji University, to share her research about the people who quietly make our everyday lives possible.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dearest Aware Bengaluru Residents,

When was the last time you thought about the chai vendor outside your office, the auto driver who gets you to work, the street food seller, the delivery partner at your doorstep? They are rarely on company payrolls, yet urban, formal life would stall without them.

Drawing from development research and everyday examples, your next lecturer Dr. Archana Rangaswamaiah unpacks the informal economy — the vast world of unregistered, unprotected labour that employs nearly 90% of India’s workforce. Far from being marginal, the informal economy acts as the invisible infrastructure of the formal one: feeding workers, absorbing economic shocks, subsidising costs, and sustaining billion-dollar industries.

The talk explores how formal and informal economies are deeply intertwined, how gender shapes informal labour, and why attempts to erase informality through policy often miss the point.

Event Details:

Time: 7PM–9PM
Date: Wednesday, 24th December
Where: Fandom at Gilly’s Redefined, Koramangala

About the lecturer

Dr. Archana Rangaswamaiah is an economic anthropologist.

She is a research fellow at Azim Premji University, anchors a livelihood initiative that examines informal labour in both rural and urban settings, critically engaging with questions of dignity, entitlements, and market relations in the contemporary context.

She completed her PhD from the University of Hyderabad. Her doctoral work explored the complexities of rural change in a capitalist economy, with a focus on agrarian distress, labour mobility, and social inequality.

Tickets

Early bird tickets (just 20 in number) are live, and as is the custom, it goes live for subscribers first. Here’s the link:

Book Tickets Here

The talk invites listeners to rethink cities, work, and value, and to ask what an economy would look like if we truly acknowledged those who keep it running.

You’ll be left wondering: what if we paused to notice the people who quietly make our everyday lives possible?

item.title: Coming Sunday, An Evolutionary Biologist Tells You Everything About Genome! [Early tix inside]
item.description: How life is written, copied, and changed. Join us for a lecture on genomes, evolution, and the tiny differences that shape life on Earth with Dr. Ashwini Mohan.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dear Reader With a Science Itch,

Imagine this.

You have a twin. Same birth, same parents, same beginnings.
One year, a river floods and spills wildly out of its banks. In the chaos, the two of you are separated. You grow up on opposite sides of that river. Ten years pass.

When you finally meet again, you look similar, but not quite. One of you is taller. The other falls sick more often. Your habits, strengths, even the way you respond to stress are different.

What changed?

Subscribe to receive early bird tickets first in your inbox

This is not a story about destiny or choice alone. It’s a story about biology. About what tiny shifts in environment can do to life: quietly, persistently, over time.

This is exactly where our next lecture begins.

In What the helix a genome?, we turn inward, to the code that writes every living thing on Earth. Long before we spoke about DNA in classrooms or crime shows, Darwin and Wallace reshaped how we understood life itself. Nearly a century later, the discovery of the “acid of life” revealed something even more astonishing: how life is written, copied, edited, and sometimes rewritten across generations.

This lecture explores what a genome really is—an organism’s entire DNA blueprint—and why its evolution matters. From population splits caused by rivers, mountains, or climate, to the long arc of how species and traits diversify, genomes carry the story of survival, adaptation, and chance. They explain why separation creates difference, and how small changes can ripple into entirely new forms of life.

Guiding us through this is Ashwini V Mohan, a postdoctoral researcher at the Biodiversity Genomics Lab at the University of Neuchâtel, Switzerland. Trained in India and Germany, Ashwini’s work spans microevolution (those subtle shifts within populations) to macroevolution, where entirely new species and traits emerge. Having worked extensively with reptile systems before pivoting to comparative genomics through a Marie Curie postdoctoral grant, her research asks one central question: how do genomes evolve, and how do their evolutionary paths shape life itself?

More recently, she has been thinking about epigenetics, how changes beyond DNA sequence can influence organisms across time, and what this means for evolution as we understand it today. Just as importantly, Ashwini is a passionate science communicator, deeply invested in mentorship, equity, diversity, and supporting women in academia.

If you’ve ever wondered why nature diverges instead of repeating itself, why separation creates novelty rather than sameness, or how life quietly records its own history inside every cell, this evening is for you.

When: Sunday, 21 December, 12 PM–2 PM

Where: Kling Brewery, Church Street

Early bird tickets dropping here. Snag them soon.

Buy ticket

Come curious.
Leave seeing life a little differently.

item.title: Coming Wednesday, Our First Lecture on History Brings You Witchcraft Stories from Rajasthan [Early Bird Tix Inside]
item.description: We are delighted to host Dr. Akhila Mathew, Assistant Professor at Azim Premji University, to talk about her historical research on caste, law and witchcraft in Rajasthan!
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dearest History Nerds,

What if we told you our first lecture on history isn’t about what most historians talk about—no kings and queens, no explorers and colonisers, but witches! Yes, Dr. Akhila Mathew goes beyond history, and makes it interdisciplinary with sociology, anthropology and law to paint the bothersome reality that permeated through early modern Rajasthan.

Subscribe for early-bird tickets!

From Harry Potter to Stree, witches have long been established as objects of popular curiosity and fascination. Yet, stepping away from these representations, one encounters a grim reality: the horrific violence perpetrated due to witchcraft accusations.

For most of us, given our social and spatial location, this violence might seem distant, most often associated with tribal communities, and the worldviews that justify the atrocities as being perpetuated due to a lack of education and/or awareness.

Moving beyond tribes and their association with witchcraft, this lecture will discuss the belief in witchcraft among the caste-based society of eighteenth-century Rajasthan. Focusing on legal records from the states of Jodhpur and Jaipur, Akhila Mathew will talk about who was believed to be a dakan (roughly translated as ‘witches’).

She will also discuss how cases concerning witchcraft were dealt with by legal institutions. Through this discussion, she will locate witchcraft within broader views on sickness and healing in eighteenth century Rajasthan (with references to present times wherever there are continuities).

About Dr. Akhila Mathew, the lecturer:

Akhila has completed her MA, MPhil, and PhD from the Centre for Historical Studies (CHS), Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), Delhi. She specialises in the social & legal history of early modern Rajasthan.

Her work engages with themes of gender, caste, and law through a study of women accused of witchcraft practices. She was awarded a PhD degree in 2021 after successfully defending her thesis titled ​‘Witchcraft, Law and State in 18th and 19th century Rajasthan’.

Before joining Azim Premji University, she taught as an ad hoc Assistant Professor for over four years at Indraprastha College for Women and St. Stephen’s College, University of Delhi.

She has been the recipient of the Charles Wallace India Trust research grant (2018) and the Nandita Prasad Sahai Memorial Trust Field Study Grant (2015).

item.title: Fantastic Trees & Where We Find Them [Early Bird Tickets Inside]
item.description: Finally, this garden city will know what all's there in the garden. Next Sunday, 14 December, 4 to 6 pm. Indiranagar.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dear Bangalorean Who Measures Time by Flowers,

We live in a city of gardens, rain trees, jacarandas, tabebuias, boulevards that purple in March and yellow in September, and lakes that may or may not actually be lakes anymore. A city where the seasons don’t just change, they bring in a colourful shift. One month the streets are carpeted with pink trumpet petals, another month it feels like the entire city is exhaling gulmohars.

We even start associating our favourite city spots with trees as icons. Like the giant Peepal tree that becomes the background for every Cubbon Reads pictures, or the beloved bookstore Champaca that almost seems suspended amongst the trees, or the boulevard when we go through on Old Airport Road.

Which is why this edition of Pint of View is called Fantastic Trees and Where We Find Them. It is not going to be just a lecture for botany enthusiasts. It’s going to become your unofficial guide to recognising the giants we walk past every day.

Ecologist Akshay Surendra will take you deep into the secret life of trees: how they are born, how they grow, how they have sex (yes, trees), how they die, and why some insist on growing everywhere while others play hard to get.

Part storytelling, part pub quiz, part ode to Bangalore’s green soul, you’ll leave this session with a sharper eye, a calmer mind, and a sensory appreciation for the trees that have been quietly holding this city together long before we arrived.

Buy ticket

So next time Bangalore blooms in a colour or a green cover you can’t name, you’ll know exactly whom to thank. And maybe, what we’re losing, and still have left to protect.

About the Lecturer:

Akshay Surendra has spent years living among wild plants in the rainforests of Sri Lanka, the Andamans, and the Western Ghats, studying how they talk to one another, compete, cooperate, and shape entire ecosystems. If you’ve ever wished someone would decode the forest for you, or at least help you distinguish a honge from an Indian beech, this is the evening to show up for.

About Pint of View:

Pint of View is inspired by the Lectures on Tap community in the U.S., and we’re bringing this format to India across major cities. It’s where big ideas meet bar tables and you leave with a drink in hand and a new way of seeing the world.

item.title: Coming Wednesday, Let a Former CERN Physicist Introduce You to String Theory & Extra Dimensions!
item.description: We're stoked to bring you Bangalore's noted physicist Dr. K. Sridhar, formerly a professor at TIFR Mumbai and currently a professor at Azim Premji University to talk about the world beyond 3D.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dearest Wonderers,

This is Harsh, one of the two founders of Pint of View. I’m introducing myself because I have a story to share with you.

In 2006, in my 11th grade, I read a beautiful book called One. Two. Three. Infinity. by the physicist George Gamow. It appeared in the recommended reading bibliography of my NCERT physics textbook, and I created a whole ruckus at home to get my hands on it. There was no Flipkart or Amazon then, so my father ended up sending someone all the way to Kolkata to find it. A month later the book finally arrived, and I devoured it cover to cover. It played a huge role in why I chose physics for my undergrad.

One of the portions I’ve never forgotten was this question: could a two-dimensional living world exist? To show why it couldn’t, Gamow used an argument so simple that even Hawking echoed it in A Brief History of Time.

Gamow wrote that a 2D living world would be impossible because the digestive system would split the animal into two halves. And it’s such an elegant way to see the limits of dimensions.

See how.


The two parts can never be joined, else digestive tract will get blocked. This quenched a curiosity which was bothersome, after all we have seen things in 2D, be it cartoons or a simple unfolded piece of paper. But my mind didn’t go further to imagine if there could be more dimensions than three. Not until we spoke with our the upcoming lecturer.

Ever since we spoke to Dr. K. Sridhar, we’ve been catching ourselves staring at ordinary things and wondering how much of the world we’re not seeing. A cup on a table. Light through a window. Someone walking past. All of it feels so confidently three-dimensional, as if the universe has already declared, “This is all there is.”

And yet physics keeps whispering that there might be more. Not metaphorical “more”, not mystical “more”, but actual directions in space that exist without ever showing themselves to us. That idea has been sitting with us all week, and we are equally excited as you to attend his upcoming lecture.

In trying to understand it, we ended up doing what we always do when something feels too big: we tried explaining it the way we would to a child.

Here’s the version that made something inside us relax.

Imagine everything in the world is made of tiny strings.
They’re too small for any microscope. Each one can wiggle in different ways. One wiggle makes something light. Another makes something heavy. Another becomes something that carries electricity. Different wiggles make different things. It’s like one guitar string playing many notes depending on how you touch it. Scientists think the whole universe might work like this, with tiny strings playing tiny notes.

And then comes the part that changes everything. For these strings to wiggle the way they need to, the universe might have more than three dimensions. Maybe these dimensions are folded so tightly that we can never walk through them. Maybe they’re curled into shapes too small to notice. Maybe they’re there, quietly influencing everything while staying forever out of sight.

This opens a whole box of questions.
If these dimensions exist, why can’t we see them?
If they’re small, can we still detect their effects?
Why haven’t decades of experiments revealed even a hint of them?
Are we missing something obvious?
Or is the universe simply more patient than we are?

These are the ideas we’ll be thinking about on 10 December, and we’re looking forward to hearing Dr. K. Sridhar wander through them in the way only he can: curious, grounded, and unwilling to pretend the universe is simple just because we wish it were.

Wednesday, 10 December 2025
7 PM to 9 PM
Fandom, Koramangala

EARLY-BIRD TICKETS ARE LIVE! Buy them here.

If you’ve ever had that feeling that the world is both familiar and utterly mysterious, I think this evening will feel like sitting with that feeling instead of pushing it aside.

We’ll be there, trying to imagine tiny strings humming in rooms of space we’ll never walk through.

Here’s about the lecture

Do we live in a world with three spatial dimensions or more? Why would we even want more than three dimensions? If there are more dimensions, why do we not see them? If these dimensions are too small to be seen, can we still find ways to discover their effects in experiments? Why have we not seen them in experiments thus far? A whole lot of questions that will engage us in this talk which will leave us thirsting for answers even as we reach out to that pint that we will very surely need by the end of the discussion.

About the lecturer

A particle physicist, K. Sridhar lived in Bombay and worked at the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research before moving to Bangalore to work at the Azim Premji University.

Dr. Sridhar completed his PhD from the University of Mumbai and did post-doctoral work at the University of London; Physical Research Laboratory, Ahmedabad and CERN, Geneva. He has had regular visiting appointments in CERN, Geneva, over the last 25 years and also in DAMTP, Cambridge; LAPP, Annecy; University of Orsay, Paris; University of Durham; University of Southampton, IPNL, Lyon and Krea University, Andhra Pradesh.

His area of work is Theoretical High-Energy Physics and his research in the field is spread over several sub-domains which include Brane Worlds and Extra Dimensions, Supersymmetry, Quantum Chromodynamics, Compositeness, and Electroweak physics.

Other than the 150-odd research papers in physics that he has published, he has a book, Brane Worlds and Extra Dimensions, in the prestigious Cambridge Mathematical Monographs Series and an edited volume, Breaking the Silo: Integrated Science Education in India. He regularly publishes articles in philosophy and the visual arts.

His first novel, Twice Written, was published in 2011, followed by a critical edition in 2019. Ajita, his second novel, was published in January 2025 by Westland Books.

So come along, and let’s see the world beyond the three dimension, without even needing 3D glasses.

Attached to strings,
Harsh, Shruti, curators, Pint of View
along with your midweek cohosts, Aayush & Rashmi!

item.title: [Wednesday Lecture] Too Hot To Handle Returns: Let's Talk About India's Climate Crisis in Kora on 3rd Dec!
item.description: We are bringing back Apekshita Varshney (Founder, Heatwatch), the lecturer who delivered the incisive and powerful third lecture for PoV and left so many of us inspired and ignited!
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dear Temperature-Sensitive Bangalore Resident,

Do you feel the chill in Bangalore air nowadays? We have been sleeping with the fan off, windows shut and blankets on. It is way different from how it used to be five years ago, when even in winters, our fans were on and one of our feet would be peeping out of the blanket for thermal equilibrium.

You’d agree that while the city is getting colder by the day, this time the dip feels different. Climate change is the obvious culprit. We often talk about erratic winters, but the quieter and deadlier side of climate change is extreme heat. In a tropical country like India, heat is the most potent form of climate danger. 80% of the country grapples with it. It slips past our attention in winter, yet it causes some of the most fatal outcomes in summer, especially for those who work demand them to be outdoors. Think labourers, gig workers, delivery men and women.

Subscribe for early bird tickets!

This edition, on popular demand, we are bringing back to you Apekshita Varshney, a journalist, a development professional, and the founder of HeatWatch, a volunteer-run initiative that tracks the human cost of rising heat. From unreported deaths to overlooked vulnerabilities, her work reveals the hidden toll of India’s growing climate crisis.

Apekshita was one of our earliest lecturers and she spoke to a packed house in our third edition, leaving so many of us ignited and inspired with her courage, charisma and conviction to take on the big corporate culprits by herself.

Why focus on labour and on revisiting official heat-death numbers? Because data from HeatWatch reveals a far graver picture than often acknowledged. As per their own summary: 11,868 people died due to heat strokes in India between 2012 and 2022, and heat waves have claimed over 24,000 lives since 1992. And in HeatWatch’s 2024 analysis, they report 733 heat-stroke deaths across 17 states between March and June — a number described as “far higher than the official toll.”

In her talk titled Too Hot to Handle Returns: India’s Growing Climate Crisis, Apekshita will explain how heat silently reshapes our lives, how unprepared our cities really are, and what building resilience could look like. She will also explore why individual emissions are meaningless when compared to the scale of large corporate emissions, and how both policy decisions and financing models can help mitigate this imbalance. This is not just an academic talk. It will leave you with a new understanding of corporate responsibility, policy gaps, and the ways in which each of us can engage meaningfully with the crisis.

Book Tickets

About Apekshita:

Meet Apekshita Varshney, the founder of HeatWatch. Apekshita is a journalist, development sector professional and campaigner who has worked with Indian and International organisations on government and corporate accountability, sustainable urban development, and climate change. She has a Master’s degree in Urban Development Planning from University College London, where she was a Commonwealth Master’s Scholar.


Tickets

Super early bird and early bird are live. Get them here.

Join us for an inspiring and eye-opening evening with conversations flowing over Geist beer on tap at Fandom at Gilly’s Redefined, Koramangala. There’s free valet parking, a 250-seater concert venue and two more perks as listed below.

item.title: Next Friday, Trade the Big Screen Drama for Better Drama Writing [Grab Early Bird Tickets]
item.description: Join Australian playwright, Julie Janson, in this lecture-workshop over drinks next Friday at Biergarten, Koramangala from 4 PM to 6 PM.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
To those who savour a well-placed line,

You’ll agree that every great story begins with someone finally saying the right thing. Or, at the very least, saying it in a way no one else was brave enough to attempt.

One of us recently started reading Miss Laila Armed And Dangerous by Manu Joseph (also, our lecturer for last Sunday). It begins like this: “When she returns from a long run she finds her neighbours standing almost naked in the compound.” One line, and suddenly we’re alert, curious, and slightly unsettled. If you agree and love reading a good drama, or if you’d like to make your current drafts stiff with passion and conversations that keep readers hooked, this one’s for you.

In our 20th session, acclaimed writer Julie Janson will take us through a lecture-and-workshop on The Art of Dialogue: how to add authenticity to our characters, how to reveal your story’s personality, voice, and motivation. Why good dialogue matters, how it shapes character and emotion, and how to make every conversation feel purposeful. From character voice to plot momentum to building suspense, this session gives you the techniques to write dialogue that breathes, crackles, and carries your story forward.

Whether you’re a first-time writer, past through a few drafts, or even just love reading a good prose but want to understand the science behind what makes it so “good”, come join us.

Get Tickets Here

This lecture-and-workshop is on The Art of Dialogue: how to add authenticity to our characters, how to reveal your story’s personality, voice, and motivation. Why good dialogue matters, how it shapes character and emotion, and how to make every conversation feel purposeful. item.title: This Wednesday, a Maths Lecture at the 250-Seater Biggest Concert Venue in Bengaluru [15% PROMO CODE INSIDE]
item.description: Yes, come attend a math lecture by Dr. Purvi Gupta from IISc with 250 others in a two-floor concert venue Fandom at Gilly's Redefined in Koramangalafrom 7pm-9pm.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Hey number-phobes and number-lovers alike,

Have you ever wondered what would happen if you got too drunk on Geist beer after one of the sessions of Pint of View and decided to walk back home? Would you ever find your way?

Sweat not, you will.

But a sober bird heading far in search of food may not.

Neither of these has anything to do with Google Maps or modern surveillance systems. Three centuries ago, Leonhard Euler had already provided proof of this through his mathematical curiosity.

In the early 20th century, David Hilbert wondered: what if a bus full of infinite guests tried to enter an already infinite hotel with a countable number of rooms? Would there be room for them?

Yes, mathematicians are curious geniuses. But why do they do what they do - try to find answers to impractical questions? Isn’t the answer to life, the universe, and everything else already established?

In our next mid-week lecture, Dr. Purvi Gupta will help us understand some popular theories in mathematics, and the joy and pointlessness of why theoretical mathematicians indulge in this world of the abstract.

Even if you’re not a math geek, and the impracticality of it all leaves you a bit confused, one thing is certain: it will be a fun introduction to the life of math and mathematicians. And hopefully, it will rekindle the joyful, pointless curiosity of your inner child!

Tickets

The lecture is on Wednesday, 26 November, 7-9 pm. And as always, you get a special promo coded as a subscriber. Use WHOLE to avail 15% off.

Snag the tickets here before they get sold out.

About the Lecture:

What is the truth about random walks and the hidden structure of dimensions. This lecture is a one stop on a curated tour of mathematical gems, which will also include a simple proof that some infinities are bigger than others, and Euler’s elegant law—a single formula that governs the shape of every three-dimensional solid, from a dice cube to a soccer ball.

About the lecturer:

Dr. Purvi Gupta is a mathematician at the Indian Institute of Science. She obtained her Ph.D. from the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, in 2015. Her research lies in multidimensional complex analysis.

Signing off before things get irrational,

Harsh, Shruti, and your midweek hosts, Aayush and Rashmi

item.title: Introducing Pint of View Experiences: 30 Spots. Intimate Venues. Masterly Hosts. Rare Access
item.description: We're delighted to take 30 of you on a journey through Silk Route via Danny and Renuka Mehra's home museum housing over 1500+ tribal rugs over food and drinks.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dear Experience Seeker,

If you’ve been loving the lectures, you’re going to love this one even more. Introducing Pint of View Experiences. 30 Spots. Intimate Venues. Masterly Hosts. Rare Access.

We couldn’t be happier to organise the inaugural experience at the home museum of two of the kindest, warmest and wisest hosts we are privileged to call as our friends, Danny and Renuka Mehra—India’s most renowned carpet collectors and storytellers. Based right here in Richmond Town Bangalore, they are opening their doors to our community-members for the first time on a guided journey through their home-museum housing 1500+ tribal rugs from the silk route, some more three hundred years old.

Step inside a home that became a museum.
What began with two gifted carpets has grown into India’s most astonishing private collection of 1,500+ tribal rugs. Danny and Renuka Mehra open their three-storey home to a tiny group of guests, inviting them to see, touch and hear the stories behind centuries-old weaves. Rugs hang like paintings, stacks rise five feet tall, and every corner holds a tale from their travels across the old Silk Road. With Danny’s inimitable eye for detail and Renuka’s warmth (and homemade cakes), this is not a tour, it’s an evening inside a living archive. Only 30 seats.

We close with a live carpet restoration demo by their in-house weaver, Imran, and of course, since it’s Pint of View, with drinks and this time, with food too! Both Renuka and our cofounder Shruti bake, and there’s going to be plenty of desserts too. Our friends at Local Ferment Co. are providing us with Kombuchas this time for everyone. :)

Tickets are live here. Since it’s just 30 spots, tickets might run out quickly, so move fast. We’ll post on Instagram later in the day, from where it might just sell out, so avail this early access soon.

Cheers.
Harsh & Shruti
Cofounders and Curators
Pint of View

item.title: Next Wednesday, 19th: A Talk Worth Its Salt Featuring Our First Food Researcher Talking About All Things Yummy & Even Mummy!
item.description: We're delighted to present to you Shivani Unakar—a food researcher and creative practitioner—to take us on a journey of what salt, yeast and chilli reveal about human curiosity, trade, and innovation.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
What if the salt on our plate, the yeast in our bread, or the chili in our curry could tell you something about who we are? In this midweek edition of Pint of View, food researcher and creative practitioner, Shivani Unakar, asks us to taste the world through the ingredients—in particular salt, yeast and chilli—that built it. If you’re thinking the lecture will center on how salt is the essential constituent in everything yummy, you’ll be pleasantly surprised to find that the lecture goes beyond and a bit into Egyptian history too, citing how salt conserved mummies there.

The lecture, How Food Taught Us Everything We Know, traces an unexpected journey across time and taste. Drawing from an intersection of anthropology, culture and the quest for power, Shivani shows how food came to define the way we live.

Subscribe to receive early-bird tickets to the upcoming lectures.

Shivani’s study is rooted in fieldwork, conversation, and the senses. She unpacks how food has shaped our identities and the civilizations we built. After her talk, if curiosity leads you deeper, you will have the chance to sit at a dinner table, not having to stare at your phone screen, but to tell profound stories of the pickles and chutneys that otherwise sit as sidies in the meal.

Here’s a short bio of the lecturer:

Shivani Unakar is a food researcher and creative practitioner based in Bangalore, India. Her work explores the intersection of food, people, and place—and how they shape identity, culture, and systems at large.

Her practice is investigative and collaborative. Through fieldwork, observation, dialogue, and sensory exploration, she approaches food as both an anchor to heritage and a bridge to evolving ways of life.

Over the past decade, her work has taken her through kitchens, farms, breweries, small businesses, FMCG brands and food media platforms, allowing her to understand Indian foodscapes across grassroots realities and larger industry shifts.

She applies this understanding to bring creative and impactful food projects to life.

About the lecture:

Some of the simplest ingredients have shaped how we understand the world.

Through a journey of three foods: salt, yeast and chili, (probably present at your tables that evening), this talk will unpack what they reveal about human curiosity, trade, and innovation evolved.

Salt taught us chemistry and preservation, yeast taught us biology and cooperation, and chili taught us geography and exchange. Together, they tell the story of how food has always been more than just sustenance. It has been a (delicious) way of learning about ourselves and the world around us.

Holding on to literal food for thought,
Harsh, Shruti and your midweek host, Aayush

item.title: A Manulogue Awaits You the Next Sunday, the 23rd! Topic of Intrigue: Why the Poor Dont Kill Us
item.description: We're delighted to host one of India's finest novelists, Manu Joseph. Known for his clever sentences & unapologetically original opinions, Manu is ready with a standup anthropology set for all of us!
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dearest Seeker,

If you read, chances are you’d have encountered our next speaker’s words or thoughts or works here or there.

For his readers, like us, he’s best known to us for writing one of the wittiest novels to have come out of India—The Illicit Happiness of Other People, which begins with the memorable first line: “Ousep Chacko, according to Mariamma Chacko, is the kind of man who has to be killed at the end of a story.” It’s a goddamn funny book, but at the same time, it’s sad to the point of depressing as well. That’s what Manu does. He finds humour in the saddest situations, and finds sadness out of the funniest situation.

Subscribe for free to receive early bird ticket details for upcoming lectures.

Consider this from his brilliant debut novel, Serious Men (yes, the same Serious Men later with Nawazuddin Siddiqui in it): “The fate of every love story, he knew very well, is in the rot of togetherness, or in the misery of separation. Lovers often choose the first with the same illusory wisdom that makes people choose to die later than now.”

Manu recently published his first work of non-fiction, and no surprises there. It’s called: Why The Poor Don’t Kill Us. And here’s the most controversial take from his latest: “Hindi cannot colonise the South because Hindi is useless.”

So we thought why not hear from the horse’s mouth. Manu is supposed to be visiting Bengaluru for only a week and we caught him just at the right time. He agreed to give a lecture on the very subject he spent last few years thinking and writing about. Why The Poor Don’t Kill Us. He said he doesn’t do PPT, and we said we don’t do a book talk, so we both acknowledged each other’s preferences and got this thing going. Manu plans to do a 40 minute straight talk, almost like a standup anthropology set, on the same topic. Knowing Manu, we knew it would be novel! So we will let Manu do the talking (do his Manulogue rather), and pepper you here with some more trivia about him, just in case.

If you’re more into pop things and haven’t heard of Manu’s name or read his works, chances are you’d have binge-watched this fun Netflix series starring Surveen Chawla and R. Madhavan (and surprise, surprise: pop icon Chetan Bhagat in the guest role!). Yes, you guessed it right! The breathtakingly yet weirdly original Indian English comedy series Decoupled also came from Manu’s pen. And if you notice the quote from Serious Men above, you’d realise the premise is exactly the same in this series.

Here’s a brief biography of Manu:

Manu Joseph is an Indian novelist, journalist, and screenwriter. He has served as editor of Open magazine and written columns for The New York Times and Hindustan Times. His novels include Serious Men (2010), The Illicit Happiness of Other People (2012), and Miss Laila, Armed and Dangerous (2017), and he created the 2021 Netflix series Decoupled.

His 2025 non-fiction book, Why the Poor Don’t Kill Us, analyzes the persistence of inequality in India and explores social, psychological, and structural reasons for the absence of large-scale revolt among the poor.

About the Lecture:

In this searing and darkly hilarious diagnosis of contemporary Indian society, the writer Manu Joseph explores why the poor don’t rise in revolt against the rich despite living in one of the most unequal regions of the world.

The poor know how much we spend in a single day, on a single meal, the price of Atlantic salmon and avocados. ‘Why,’ he asks, ‘do they tolerate it? Why don’t they crawl out from their catastrophes and finish us off? Why don’t little men emerge from manholes and attack the cars? Why don’t the maids, who squat like frogs beside kitchen sinks, pull out the hair of their conscientious madams who never give them a day off? Why is there peace?’

Structured like a standup anthropology set, in his lecture Why the Poor Don’t Kill Us, Manu will show us in pitiless detail just how hypocritical and exploitative people of privilege are, and it also shows us how and why they get away with it. Come prepared for a sharp, witty, and perceptive critique of the many faults of the India we live in.

P.S. For the fans, while there won’t be an official book signing because we don’t wish to turn this into a typical book talk, you can get your copies of Manu’s books to get them signed by him post the lecture.

Tickets

If you’re in town this Sunday, 16th, we have the rarest of the rare lectures happening in India at our Bangalore venue:

Dr. Saugata Barat, an expert and a Ph.D. on Exoplanets—planets outside of our solar system—is coming all the way from MIT for only a couple of months to India, and he is doing three lectures at Pint of View chapters across Bangalore, Delhi and Mumbai. He’d the only such exoplanet expert to be visiting India this time, so make sure you don’t miss it. Only last few tickets are left for his lecture. As a newsletter subscriber, we got you a 10% off coupon: use PLANETS to avail them. Book here!

Cheers.

Knowing our audience will turn this manulogue into a dialogue,
Harsh & Shruti

item.title: [Beginner-Friendly] Presenting Back to Back Astrophysics Lectures The Coming Week: Black Holes on Wednesday 9th & Exoplanets on Sunday 15th. Early Bird Tix Inside!
item.description: Come next week, Bangalore is all set to be floored by two brilliant physicists: an MIT Post Doc with a Ph.D. in Exoplanets Atmospheres and a Harvard Ph.D. & a TIFR Professor and Expert on Black Holes.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
We know it’s late! We’ll keep it short.

Here are the two posters and the two bio. Book early bird tickets as soon as you can. From our experience, both of these will get sold out very soon—faster than you think!

Subscribe for free for early-bird ticket updates.

About the Sunday Lecture (4pm-6pm, 16th Nov, Jamming Goat 3.0, Indiranagar)

From Sci-Fi to Sci-Fact—Unravelling the Atmosphere of Exo-Worlds!

In just three decades, what once belonged to the realm of science fiction has become science fact. Astronomers have discovered more than 6,000 planets orbiting stars beyond our Sun, each one stranger than the next.

From blazing lava worlds locked in eternal daylight to stormy gas giants with winds faster than a fighter jet, from planets cloaked in glass-sand clouds to teenage worlds shedding their atmospheres into space; these exoplanets have upended our ideas of what a planet can be.

In this talk, we’ll embark on an expedition across this vast and surprising exoplanet landscape. We’ll see how astronomers find these distant worlds, how we read the secrets of their atmospheres from faint starlight, and where the next generation of telescopes may finally glimpse another Earth and perhaps, signs of biosignatire!

We’re lucky to catch hold of the MIT Post-doc Dr. Saugata Barat who’s visiting India for a very short duration, all thanks to his wife Kamalika who reached out to us just in time.

About the Wednesday Lecture (Jolly Johnny’s Bar, 7pm-9pm, Wed, 12th Nov)

A basic principle of physics is that time evolution is always reversible: given knowledge of the present, we can reconstruct the past and predict the future. But it is a challenge to preserve this principle when we combine the theory of gravity, which predicts the existence of black holes, with quantum mechanics, which governs the microscopic world. This is a problem in theoretical physics, but also one that has philosophical implications. In this talk, we will discuss some recent progress on this problem.

About The Speaker

Dr. Suvrat Raju is a physicist at the International Centre for Theoretical Sciences of the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research. A Ph.D. from Harvard (2008), he works on string theory, quantum gravity and quantum field theory.

He is known for his pioneering work on black holes and is a recipient of the ICTP Prize in 2019 and the Nishina Asia Award in 2022.

BOTH THESE LECTURES ARE PERFECTLY PALATABLE BY BEGINNERS. So come with an open mind and dazzle your mind. :)

  2. Exoplanet Atmospheres: 4pm-6pm, Sunday, 16th Nov, in Indiranagar. Early bird tickets here.

item.description: For our 13th Sunday lecture, we got you Dr. Padmini Ray Murray, feminist researcher, maker and Founder, Design Beku to talk about design justice.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dear Fellow Seeker,

We’re in love with the next topic. Being in Bengaluru and that too in the startup circles, we detest the word “hustle” and the hustle culture it propagates, and we’re always looking for people who are as contrarion as us. At last, we found someone as opinionated but not just superficially, but in depth, about another buzz word in the startup circle: “design thinking”.

Subscribe for early bird tickets for upcoming lectures.

We’re delighted to bring to you the next lecturer. Dr. Padmini Ray Murray, a feminist researcher, maker and Founder, Design Beku, with her provocative lecture next Sunday at Jamming Goat 3.0 titled (wait for it):

It hits the hammer on the head. And we’ll keep this newsletter short and let the topic and the biography of Padmini do the talking.

About the Speaker:

Dr Padmini Ray Murray is a feminist researcher, maker and the founder of Design Beku - a collective of researchers, artists, technologists and designers who work towards making design and digital practice more locally rooted, community-led, contextually relevant and ethical.

Her research and practice focuses on challenging acts of infrastructural and algorithmic violence, and creating alternative digital spaces and imaginations that are characterised by feminist values, specifically an ethics of care. Design Beku has partnered with a range of community based organisations and NGOs such as Enable India, Point of View, Sangama, Maya Health, and Janastu on projects which range from feminist digital interventions, public health, and digital self determination for people with disabilities.

About the Lecture:

When you think about design, chances are you think about design thinking: an approach now widely used everywhere: from corporate spaces to NGOs. But what is it, and why is it so popular? And are there alternative ways of designing in a world teetering on the brink of collapse? In this talk, Padmini will track the story of design thinking and why it’s done more harm than good, and explore what the alternatives can be.

item.title: Midweek Lecture Alert (Early Bird Tix Inside!): An UnFROGettable Lecture Awaits You on Wed, 5th Nov in Koramangala
item.description: For our 12th lecture, we are stoked & croaked to bring you one of India's leading herpetologists—Dr Seshadri KS, Faculty, Centre for Biodiversity Conservation, ATREE to speak about frogs!
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Hello Fellow Nature Geek,

In the ten lectures we hosted so far, one thing has been clear: Bangalore absolutely loves nature. Be it bats, birds or moths, we had a super curious lot brimming with hundreds of questions, which our lecturers patiently answered. We realised we can’t keep our community away from nature for long, and we wondered what if we can talk about a species which often become forgettable (or should we say frogettable?) post monsoons.

The monsoons are over — or so we would like to believe in Bangalore. As we get ready to mark the last few weeks of the year, seems like the frogs will also disappear from our sights. So we thought why not find someone who can shed more light (or rain) on them?

Given how rare it is to spot frogs in Bangalore, we wondered what a frog researcher was doing in the city! But it turns out, even amidst the challenges posed by unseasonal rains and urbanisation, *frogs continue to persist*. *A recent study has shown that despite urbanization, frogs and toads persist in the city, in remnant habitats around wetlands and parks.*

But how different is its life from that of the frogs that live in the tall forest canopies? Or from those who sing immaculately and those who dote on their offsprings sitting inside bamboo reeds? Where do they disappear after the monsoons? How vast and secretive is their world?

The subject was fascinating enough. So when Aisiri Amin introduced Seshadri to us, and we were welcomed courtesy a mutual interest in terrible jokes (read: word-play), we jumped on the opportunity to know more about the world of amphibians through him.

The subject was fascinating enough. So when our journalist friend Aisiri Amin (who recently wrote about us in Conde Nast) introduced Dr. Seshadri to us, and we were welcomed courtesy a mutual interest in terrible jokes (read: bad puns and word-play), we jumped on the opportunity to know more about the world of amphibians through him.

We’re delighted to bring you the first such lecture on frogs, happening at Jolly Johnny’s Bar in Koramangala, Wednesday, 7 pm - 9 pm.

About the Lecture:

UnFROGettable encounters is a collection of stories on the fascinating lives of amphibians: Frogs that live in the tall forest canopies, frogs that sing immaculately, and those which dote their offspring sitting inside bamboo reeds. Come, learn about frogs and toads so you can let them hop closer to your hearts!

About the Lecturer:

Dr. Seshadri K. S. is a second-generation Bangalorean who grew up surrounded by nature, watching sparrows nest in a well in his courtyard during the early 1990s. He is currently a faculty member at ATREE, leading a vibrant lab group focused on a wide range of ecology and biodiversity conservation issues in the broad themes of urban ecology and community ecology. He teaches courses for Master’s and PhD students, as well as mentoring interns, many of whom have gone on to establish their careers in ecological research. In his spare time, Seshadri enjoys writing, tending to his rooftop garden, reading books, and making bad jokes.

item.title: Are You Being Fooled? Well, that's the topic of our next lecture! (Early Bird Tix Inside!)
item.description: Join Prof. Kanchan Kaur—Journalist, Educator & Media Literacy Advocate—as she takes us through how AI is transforming media, blurring lines between truth and illusion, and how we can be a step ahead.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dearest Meaning Seeker (also, the occasional doomscroller!),

We know how much you love scrolling through reels on Instagram and later finding hours gone. Sometimes willingly, but most times, unwillingly. We know, we know! We know because most likely you’d have come across Pint of View in one of those doomscrolling sessions, and you might have thought, finally there is something to do in Bangalore that is meaningful and regularly so!

Like you, we too are a sucker for meaning! So much so that we ended up turning our beloved Cubbon Park into a reading haven, after realising how joyful it is just to lounge there on a mat and simply read in silence (the best part—5g doesn’t work in that part of the park!). So much so that after getting tired of all the face-obsessed dating apps, we built a dating app for readers, where one swipes books, not looks (faces are only revealed after 10 messages each!).

But despite all the tiny communities we built and all the meaning we sought from books and people, it didn’t save us from the meaninglessness of doomscrolling, which we’re equally guilty of, if not more, as active creators ourselves. We know, a lot of good content floats on these platforms, a lot of good creators are constantly pulling off creative things to keep the platform new and informative, but we have also worryingly seen it get taken over by AI content and misinformation over time.

Subscribe for early bird tickets of next lectures!

While we could develop enough critical thinking to chuck the Whatsapp University gyaan coming our way in Whatsapp family groups, or to completely shun off TV news from our lives, misinformation and AI content have very sneakly crept into the feeds Instagram and Twitter curate for us everyday during our daily doomscroll. And the lines there get really blurry.

Since reels are visual, consider this image. Can you spot which one is real and which is not?

The left one is real. The one on the right is AI. This might have been easy, right? The neatness of AI gives it away. But when human faces are involved, it gets tricky. Consider the one image below. Which one do you think is AI? Comment your answer and we’ll reveal whether you’re right or not in our replies.

What if we told you there was a toolkit to sniff AI-content from real one? As writers, we can use some straightforward pointers. Too many em dashes? A punchy “it’s not just this, but that” construction? Or the biggest giveaway: Oxford commas (the comma before an and, like one in the poster subtitle below) which most Indians don’t even know how to use. All these are ChatGPT.

But how do you sniff it in news, in images, and in media of all kinds. Precisely for that, we bring you the expert lecturer!

Prof. Kaur is an authority on Media Literacy and has been a journalist and journalism educator for 40+ years. Here is more about her lecture, followed by a brief biography of hers.

Are you being fooled?

At a time when Artificial Intelligence is reshaping how information is created, shared, and perceived, media literacy is no longer optional — it’s essential. AI tools now enable anyone to generate highly plausible text, audio, video and images. Deep fakes proliferate, algorithms push sensational content and large language models can hallucinate false claims and produce misleading narratives. These shifts raise serious challenges for individuals, societies, and democratic institutions.

Media literacy equips people with critical thinking tools to navigate this complexity. It involves skills to question sources, to recognise manipulated or AI-generated content, to verify claims through reputable sources, and to understand how recommendation algorithms and filter bubbles shape what we see.

Media literacy has proactive value: it allows citizens to participate more responsibly in public discourse, to demand accountability from platforms and content creators, to resist manipulation and disinformation, and to preserve trust in institutions. Teachers, news organisations, policy-makers and tech companies all have roles to play — from building curricula that include AI-specific literacy, to ensuring transparency in how content is labelled or generated, to providing accessible tools for verification.

As AI amplifies both opportunity and risk, media literacy is the guardrail that helps us benefit from AI without losing our ability to separate fact from fiction, truth from manipulation.

Short Profile of Prof. Kaur

Kanchan Kaur brings nearly forty years of hands-on experience in journalism and journalism education. She has been a reporter across varied beats — crime, politics, environment, technology — at leading news organisations such as The Indian Express (New Delhi), Deccan Herald (Bengaluru), and Gulf News (Dubai). She later shifted to training, teaching reporting, writing, and multimedia journalism. For two decades at the Indian Institute of Journalism and New Media (IIJNM), she taught many courses and served as Dean for over a dozen years, ensuring curricula stayed current and students were industry-ready.

Kaur has also collaborated with international institutions — Earlham College, University of Technology Sydney, Poynter Institute, Google News Initiative, BBC Young Reporter Programme, among others. Since 2015, her work has focused on News and Media Literacy, including curriculum building, workshops, and advisory roles. She believes that everyone should be introduced to the wonderful world of journalism.

item.title: The Curious Incident of the Moth in the Night-Time
item.description: For our 10th lecture happening at our usual hang Jamming Goat 3.0 on Sunday, 26th October, we're bringing you Dr. Pritha Dey, a moth biologist and an evolutionary ecologist.
item.dc:creator: Pint of View
item.content:encoded:
Dearest Fellow Nerd,

Did you know some moths can disguise themselves as leaves or bark to avoid predators? They navigate by moonlight, often confused by our streetlights, and males can detect a female’s scent from over ten kilometers away. Moths are also vital night-time pollinators—and some, like the Luna Moth, don’t eat at all, living just long enough to find love before fading away.

Happy Diwali in advance! We’re on a science trip this month. From the Moon, neuroscience, Mars, birds to now moths. If the last month was about the arts—visual thinking, environment, textiles—October is consumed by sciences (barring a fun midweek lecture on geopolitics happening in Koramangala on the 29th!).

For the post-Diwali Sunday, 26th October, we’re delighted to bring to you Dr. Pritha Dey in an insightful yet fun lecture on moths.

We met Pritha almost two years ago at a friend’s New Year party, and yes, we were as blown by what her specialisation was in. Where does one find moth biologists just like that? We kept in touch, following her deeply interesting work on Instagram, and the moment we got a chance, we reached out to her and she agreed for a lecture. We did a demo lecture already, and some facts just were mind-boggling.

About the talk:
Moths are among the most diverse and ecologically important insect groups, yet they often go unnoticed in our own backyards. This talk introduces the fascinating world of moths, highlighting their diversity, ecological roles, and how anyone, regardless of background, can begin observing and identifying them using simple techniques.

From setting up light traps to photographing and recording species, we’ll explore practical tools and methods to turn everyday spaces into windows to nocturnal biodiversity. Whether you’re a curious beginner or a seasoned naturalist, this session will open your eyes to the fascinating, hidden world of moths just outside your door.

About the lecturer:
Dr. Pritha Dey is the Head of Natural History Collections at the National Centre for Biological Sciences (NCBS), Bangalore, with research spanning the taxonomy, diversity, and evolutionary ecology of moths, shaped by fieldwork in the Western Himalayas and Western Ghats. Beyond research, she actively engages in science communication and outreach, and also serves as the Country Coordinator for National Moth Week in India.

Early bird tickets to the moth lecture are live. You can book them here. Early bird runs out in as little as five minutes so hurryyyyy.

Today evening, if you happen to be in town, take advantage of the low traffic situation and come for the bird lecture. We have a salsa dancing wildlife scientist and a NatGeo explorer all the way from Hyderabad coming in for it. The lecture will end with a dance! How cool is that?

That’s it for now! Wishing you a happy and safe Diwali, and in case you wish for us to invite a lecturer of your choice, write to us at pintofview.club@gmail.com! We’ll get them for you. We’re keenly looking for musicians (singer/songwriters) who can do a lecture on songwriting, and bakers and brewers who can speak about the science of baking and brewing.

Mothentically yours,
Harsh & Shruti
Curators, Pint of View
